<lj-embed id="2"/>

"Avenue Q" and "Fiddler on the Roof" equals "Avenue Jew."  (I know it's old- I first saw it three years ago, but it's still awesome!)
I'm singing the National Anthem for the Sacramento Rivercats (our baseball team) on Wednesday, June 24.
I melted my jacket trying to keep warm at work.

If you have not seen it, find it and watch "The Room."

http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0368226/

I have now seen Mr. Tommy Wiseau's cinematic tour-de-force, `The Room' three times. With each viewing, `The Room' becomes more complexly entangled in and inseparable from my own life. I no longer know where The Room ends and I begin.

It is, without question, the worst film ever made. Including movies made on beta max video cameras in special education high school classes. But this comment is in no way meant to be discouraging. Because while The Room is the worst movie ever made it is also the greatest way to spend a blisteringly fast 100 minutes in the dark. Simply put, `The Room' will change your life.

It's not just the dreadful acting or the sub-normal screenplay or the bewildering direction or the musical score so soaked in melodrama that you will throw up on yourself or the lunatic-making cinematography; no, there is something so magically wrong with this movie that it can only be the product of divine intervention. If you took the greatest filmmakers in history and gave them all the task of purposefully creating a film as spectacularly horrible as this not one of them, with all their knowledge and skill, could make anything that could even be considered as a contender. Not one line or scene would rival any moment in The Room.

The centerpiece of this filmic holocaust is Mr. Tommy Wiseau himself. Without him, it would still be the worst movie ever made, but with him it is the greatest worst movie ever made. Tommy has been described as a Cajun, a Croatian cyborg, possibly from Belgium, clearly a product of Denmark, or maybe even not from this world or dimension. All of these things are true at any one moment. He is a tantalizing mystery stuffed inside an enigma wrapped in bacon and smothered in cheese. You will fall in love with this man even as you are repelled by him from the first moment he steps onto screen with his long Louis the Fourteenth style black locks and thick triangular shoulders packed into an oddly fitting suit, and his metallic steroid destroyed skin. Tommy looks out of place, out of time and out of this world. There has never been anything else like him. Nor will there ever be.

The Room begins with `Johnny' (Tommy Wiseau) and his incomprehensibly evil fiancée `Lisa' (played by a woman with incongruously colored eyebrows and a propensity for removing her shirt) engaging in some light frottage, joined by, Denny, (played with a deft sense of the absurd by Phillip Haldiman), their sexually confused teenage neighbor who is clearly suffering from a form of aged decrepitude. When Denny, who looks like the human version of Gleek the monkey from Superfriends, says, in a slightly creepy yet playful tone of voice, `I like to watch!' as Johnny and Lisa roll around the bed in a pre-intercourse ritual revolving around rose petals, you know you are in for a very special movie.

After a lengthy lovemaking scene (not to worry if you miss it the first time, they show it again in its entirety later in the movie) in which Tommy's bizarre scaly torso and over-anatomized rear-end are lovingly depicted over and over again as he appears to hump Lisa's hip, we discover that Lisa, for no particular reason, has become bored with Tommy's incessant lovemaking and decides to leave him.

Just when you think the movie might lapse into an ordinary, pedestrian sort of badness, Johnny's best friend Mark, a man who's job seems to be to wear James Brolin's beard from Amityville Horror, shows up and electrifies the screen with a performance so wooden that it belongs in the lumber section of Home Depot. Incidentally, Mark is played by Greg Sestero, who, in addition to being described as a department store mannequin, was also the line producer on `The Room' and one of Tommy Wiseau's five (5!!!!!) assistants on the movie. Lisa forces Mark, amid his paltry, unconvincing protests, to have an affair with her on their uncomfortable circular stairs. For no apparent reason Lisa decides that she is made of pure evil and wants to torture her angelic and insanely devoted fiancé, Johnny.

Lisa receives pointed advice from her mother who casually announces that she is dying of breast cancer and then never mentions it again. But Lisa is determined to make Johnny's life a living hell, in spite of the fact that she, according to her mother, "cannot survive on her own in the cutthroat 'computer business'". But not before they recycle the sex scene from earlier in the movie where we get another bird's eye view of Johnny's ludicrous naked body. Denny gets into trouble with a drug dealer. Mark shaves his beard. Tommy gets drunk on an unusual cocktail made from mixing whiskey and vodka. Lisa lies and tells everyone that Tommy hit her in a drunken rage.

A balding psychologist appears out of nowhere, offers some advice, then apparently dies while softly falling on the ground in an attempt to catch a football thrown by Mark.

All of these seemingly disparate events build up to two cathartic moments. The first is when Tommy expressively yells at Lisa with the line `You are tearing me apart Lisa!'. You will cheer at this line as you realize that the film has been tearing you apart the whole time. And the second is at Tommy's birthday party where the worst actor that has ever been born plays a unidentified man wearing a silk shirt who utters a phrase that perfectly describes the experience of watching The Room,

`It feels like I'm sitting on atom bomb that is going to explode!'

The shocking ending will leave you pleading for some kind of sequel.

See this film at all costs. See it twice. Or three times. Or as one kid that I met from Woodland Hills has, 12 times! See it until you can recite every precious line of dialogue this movie has to offer. Let The Room become your new religion and Tommy Wiseau your prophet preaching the gospel according to Johnny.

My dream is to someday buy a theater and run The Room 24 hours a day, 7 days a week until the print disintegrates. I hope it becomes your dream as well.

Hey everyone!

One of my friends is having a birthday on Saturday, and I made her a paper crown that amuses me.  It's more for display than practical use (which I should have thought of and will elaborate on in a moment), and it is silly and fun.

If I make another one: I will think about the fact that it is mainly for display and therefore make sure that the bottom edge is even.  This one is curved, which is why I stuck it in the Christmas Tree to take photos (it wouldn't sit straight on the table).  I'm a little afraid to try and fix it since I like the way it came out, and don't really want to screw it up.

Photos are here

 

Front View


Side View


Back View
  



I think I'm going to go out tomorrow and get red and green paper and make Christmas ones for my family.  I was able to turn this one out in a few hours, so there's enough time for me to do them.  And I might make a couple and see if the local paper store wants to buy them (they used to have some that were made by an artist who just had a baby and quit making them).  If not, I'll try to sell them on Etsy, I think.

If you have comments or reccommendations, please leave them here!

Someone I know is spearheading this, and it's catching on in Sacramento as far as I know.  Thought I'd spread the word.



Hello friends,

The people of California have voted for an amendment that adds bigotry to our constitution. Clearly the citizens of this state do not see gay and lesbian citizens as deserving of the same basic rights to which the heterosexual community have an automatic entitlement. We are not important to California.


In order to show the state that gays and lesbians are a vital part of society, and to show our displeasure at this horrific turn in the history of California, I am calling for Monday, December 1, 2008 to be “Calling in Gay” day. On this day, I implore all gay and lesbian members of California to call in sick to their places of employment. If we are not important enough to California to have the same rights as others, then surely we will not be missed for one day.


I am also asking that on December 1, 2008, all gay and lesbian citizens of California not spend their hard earned money anywhere in the state. Again, if our lives have such little importance not to warrant the same basic freedoms as others, then one day without our cash flow will be of little consequence to California.


Spend the day at home with loved ones and friends and enjoy the day knowing that California is doing just fine without us!

This will only get our message across if a) we all commit to taking a stand, and b) we send this to as many people across California as we can.

Do not let this chance to express our displeasure pass us by!

Let’s make our voices, and our displeasure, heard.


Thank you.

Yay Halloween!

And best wishes to cuddlycthulu and chelleann!

I love my work!!!

There will be more soon, but now it's time for bed.

While I'm on the subject of fabulous dresses, I found a large stash of amazing things that I must share.  I'm stuffing them behind a cut so I don't wreck your friends page.

These are at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and I desperately want to go see them in person.


Pretty!


I want my next ball gown to look like this.


I love the colors on this.


This looks so elegant.


I guess I just like the black and white stuff.  (See the first "I want this" post)


If I have to wear a bustle dress in a show again, I'm going to show this to the designer and say "I want this."


Now we're getting into the things that are so ridiculous that you simply must love them!  I wish they'd had an image of the front of this one.


And I can't help but laugh at this.


Here's the side view of the one above.
I sold my trombone- thank you to those who expressed interest.

Hey everyone!

Going through my closet, I found two dust-covered instruments that I want to sell.  I thought I'd give my friends a shot at them before random strangers. 

I have a beautiful antique silver Conn Baritone/Euphonium (it's really a euphonium, but the difference between the two is negligable) and a professional-grade Trombone with an F attachment.  It's a Bach Stradivarius 42B Open Wrap.

Both are high-quality instruments, and I'm selling them for very reasonable prices.

If you or anyone else you know is interested, please send me an email at: thecalligrapher at gmail dot com and I'll happily provide more in-depth information.

Thanks!

I was visiting from Washington, D.C., and was blown away by the performance. The lead singer belongs on Broadway. I bought the sheet music and have been playing it at home.
- Michael Doan

This means you should come see my show.

There are more reviews at http://www.seeaplay.com/productionsReviewsLittle.htm

If you're planning on seeing my show- this is it!  One weekend left- that's three performances.

Friday, April 4- 8:00.
Saturday, April 5- 4:00.
Sunday, April 6- 2:30.

The box office number is 530.642.0404.

Call and reserve your seats.  We are hoping to sell out.

If you're coming, let me know (otherwise I'll sneak out of the back door, and I won't say hi to you).

Tickets are $16 for adults, $9 for 18 and under, $13 for seniors (though I don't think that anyone who reads this would qualify for that).

The theater is at 100 Placerville Dr, Placerville, CA.

It's totally worth it the trip!  I love my show, and so has everyone else who has seen it.  We want to sell the shows out, but we're not there yet.  Particularly on Friday night.  As of yesterday, we'd only sold about 40 seats (we seat 185- and can add up to 15 more seats).  I'd love it if we had to add seats.

I'm trying not to get all wrapped up in the fact that it's the end of our run.  I'm going to miss this show so terribly.  We had our cast party, and the DVDs got passed out (they are pretty much as bad as I thought they would be- and I might devote an entry to that subject.  It is very interesting to watch the recording before the end of the run).

Anyhow- I've got to quit writing about the end of the show before I get all depressed and weepy.

Please come see me!

"The tale was captivating and the music was evoking. The actors seemed very comfortable in their roles and acted very naturally. Jo was firey and driven, and had a beautiful singing voice. I was very pleased with this show and highly reccomend it to everyone.  :) "

www.seeaplay.com

Everyone has things they blog about. Everyone has things they don't blog about. Challenge me out of my comfort zone by telling me something I don't blog about, but you'd like to hear about, and I'll write a post about it. Ask for anything: latest movie watched, last book read, political leanings, thoughts on religion, favorite type of underwear, random techniques, etc. Repost in your own journal so that we can all learn more about each other!

Or alternatively you can ask me a question, and I will answer it.

This show is a must see! Possibly one of the best shows this theater has produced! (and I've been to many of IT's shows). The casting is excellent and each and every actor is talented and perfect for their role. The lead Jo is enthusiastic, touching and funny, and what a voice! The mix of the live band, singing, and characters are kismet! DON'T MISS THIS SHOW! It's a little slice of Broadway in the foothills!  from www.seeaplay.com

Hell yes!  That's what I like to hear.

Snoopy came to see it- he said "Since when has your voice been able to blow down barn doors?"

Anyone else coming?  We've got four more weekends.  As this person said- Don't miss this show!

Tomorrow, we have our "Student Night."  It should be interesting.  There's a Q&A session after the show.  But I'm terrified that the questions will be lame.

So- here's your project: if you have any questions that you think could lead to interesting theater-based discussion, I would love for you to leave them here.  It'll give me good ideas for tomorrow, and gives you an opportunity to ask away.

Thank you for your help!

http://www.seeaplay.com/productionsReviewsLittle.htm

Read them!

And if you've seen it, write one of your own!

YAY!

Will write more when I regain consciousness.

Thank  you all for the sore-throat reccommendations.  Hot tea with honey and lemon did the trick!  I kicked ass at rehearsal tonight.

BUT- I got some unnerving news.  There are some performances that have no tickets pre-sold.  If we don't get people to buy tickets to those shows in advance, they will be cancelled.

So- if you're considering coming to see me, pick a date and reserve your tickets NOW.  You don't want to risk driving all the way to Placerville just to find out that the show was cancelled, now do you?

The box office number is 530.642.0404.  Tickets are $9 students and $16 adults.  The dates and times are listed on http://megmasterson.net.  Go to the "Performances" section.

CALL.  NOW.

Please.

I promise, the show is good!  I wouldn't tell you to waste your time and money on a bad show.

I made it through the worst part of the winter without incident.  When EVERYONE around me was sick, I hung in there.

We Preview Tmorrow.  Our final rehearsal is tonight.

My voice is starting to go.

This is not amusing.

I'm doing everything that I can to preserve/fix/help my voice.  If anyone has any super-secret amazing remedy, Please let me know.  Unfortunately, I'm at work and don't have a lot of opportunity to get supplies, and I'm headed straight to the theater afterward, but there's just enough time for me to stop in at the market if necessary.

Enlighten me, friends, I need your help: how do I fix my voice?

Little Women is in the Paper!

Here's a link: http://www.mtdemocrat.com/digital_media.php?month=02&day=22&year=2008&submit=t&page=0

I'm in the upper left corner of the front page, the front page of the Entertainment section (B), and the article on B-1 continues on B-5.

The first hunk of the article is all about Louisa May Alcott, but we get down to stuff about our show after "It's the Music" which is at the bottom of the middle column on B-1.

Read it.

And what Peter says about me made me cry.

We open in a week!  My God, this is so cool.  It's so hard to describe.  Maybe I'll try to do that later.

Until then, I'll spread the word that I'm in the paper!

We open a week from tomorrow!  We open a week from tomorrow!  We open a week from tomorrow!  We open a week from tomorrow!  We open a week from tomorrow!  We open a week from tomorrow!

I never thought it'd happen.

Eight days.

Oh my God!  We've been working on this for so long...  I'm seriously stressed out about it- but it's the good kind of stress- the kind that makes you up your game and take everything to the next level and make your performance as good as you can make it.

AAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

ok- off to rehearsal.  I'm going to kick ass, and take no prisoners.

Will write more soon.

By the way, I want to know who is coming to see me, and when.  I know that Snoopy is coming up with a crew of people on March 1.  Anyone else coming?  (You really should- I wouldn't tell you to come see me in a bad show.  Remember Cinderella and High School Musical?  I don't recall telling people that they really should come to those shows.  You REALLY SHOULD come see this one.)  And when you buy your tickets, tell them that Jo sent you.

Work today was decent- we got swamped at the end of the day, though.  It kind of sucked then, but the rest of the day was pretty good. 

Last night's rehearsal was amazing.  We worked through "Could You" the duet between Jo and Aunt March, and it's significantly improved now.  I'm looking forward to doing it again.  We also did both of my big solos- "Astonishing" and "The Fire Within Me"- and worked out all the little details that are going to make them all that much more awesome. 

It's funny- sometimes, it's just these small tiny things that feel so perfect in the moment and are the most fun things you get to do!  Just the slightest movement can feel so perfect!  It's hard to describe, but when you get it right, there's nothing in the world like it. 

Tonight, I have a makeup work shop thinger with someone who is supposed to know what she is doing.  There's going to be about half of the cast there, and I'm hoping that it'll be fun.  Well, I'm sure that it will be. 

Tomorrow morning, I have an errand to run, then dashing off to rehearsal! 

We're getting our microphones for real tomorrow.  The sound guy's going to be there at noon to set us all up.  I'm totally nervous, but it'll be fine.  It's just different. 

We're also doing a photo shoot tomorrow.  It should be cool!  It's for a local newspaper.  I hope that I don't wind up looking like a total moron.  We'll see. 

Got to get ready for makeup thing!  And prep for tomorrow's rehearsal from Hell- sound, costumes, lights, and orchestra. 

Wish me luck!

Kate (Meg) was kind enough to take photos and video during rehearsal the other night.  These are screencaps from the video- so it's not the highest quality (but not that bad)- and some of the photos are really great!


The Attic


"My great adventure has begun!"


Professor Bhaer and Jo- and the Obnoxious dress!


"If I say, 'Let me share your small umbrella...'"


"How can I explain?"


Waiting for the band to straighten themselves out...


SWISH!!!


INCOMING!  This is just after the Professor tells Jo that someone wants to publish "Little Women."


Swishing around- now you see why I love this dress!


Further swishing!





"Marmee!  This is a... good friend of mine.  Professor Fritz Bhaer."

...You're ironing the pleated trim on the underskirt of the monstrous dress and think, "I must be almost done by now."

Then you check.

And find that you're hardly a quarter of the way through.

Good heavens, that dress is tremendous.

On another somewhat related note- I'm going to start taking singing lessons!  (And now you ask "How the hell is that somewhat related?"  Well- I was talking about the Monstrous dress, which is what I wear for "Small Umbrella in the Rain," which I sing with Professor Bhaer, who is played by Jeremy, who has agreed to give me voice lessons!  See- it's related.)

I'm excited about it- I'll probably start later this week or next week.

Yay!

Back to the ironing board.

Behind the Cut...









Jo, Meg, Marmee, Beth, and Amy.


Enjoy!

I got cast in Gondoliers!

I have a small part (much like my part in HMS Pinafore last year).  My name is Vittoria.

YAY!  I didn't think they'd give me a named part since I wasn't able to go to callbacks.  But they did!  Hurrah! 

Now back to your regularly scheduled programming...

I cut my hair.  A while ago.  After Little Women auditions.  It's short now.

Had to do it for the part: Jo sells her hair so Marmee can go take care of Father when he's sick.

So I have short hair again.  I like it.  I'm hoping to get a decent photo of me soon, which I'll post eventually.

Just thought I'd mention it since I didn't think I had yet...

Today, Peter was giving me blocking notes for the song "Days of Plenty."  I don't sing- it's Marmee's solo- but I'm onstage for the whole thing.

You know it's bad when just writing down the blocking notes makes you cry.

Really cry.

It's going to be so so sad.

You'll all have to come and see it.  Really- this show is amazing.  If you ever thought it'd be fun or nice to take a road trip and come see me perform, this is going to be the one to see!

But bring your handkerchiefs.

I already got Peter to say I could carry a handkerchief onstage.  Thank God.  I'm going to need it really REALLY bad.

You should see it.  It's going to be amazing.

If you're on my f-list, then there's something that I appreciate about you. You might feel that appreciation already, but then again you might not. This is my way of letting you know that you are appreciated:

Please leave a comment, and I will tell you at least one thing that I appreciate about you. We can all use a little validation from our friends or even strangers from time to time, so if you want to know what I appreciate about you, this is your chance to find out. If you feel like posting this in your own journal, feel free to pay it forward.

My Mom loves me.

She bought me a fog machine for Halloween.

So on Halloween, I'm going to set it up under the bridge on our walk way, put up signs that say "Beware of Trolls", hide under the bridge with the fog machine, and bang on the underside of the bridge as trick-or-treaters approach.

Oh yes.

It shall be grand.

I am no longer a part of The Broccoli Club.  I'll detail this later, if I feel like it.

Just know that it did not end well, and I will only ever audition for theater companies that have established themselves (unless extraordinary circumstances arise).

To be blunt- they replaced me.  So I left.

I don't think I'll be attending their show.

I'm going to run to the market and buy some ice cream now.  And let the Little Women people know that I won't be missing those rehearsals this week.  So there.  Dammit.

I received official notification of getting the part of Jo on Sunday night (though Saturday night I was told unofficially).

It is now Thursday night, and I'm still buzzing!

It's truly amazing.

Tonight, we just went through some character analysis type things.  It was good.  We also were asked about parallels to our own lives- I already told Peter (the director) that I once wished to be the next Great American Novelist.  He thought it was intriguing that I wrote a book.

I was also sitting with Tammy, who is our Marmee, and I was sitting quite informally.  She looked at me and laughed.  "You're already getting in character?"
I laughed even harder, "No- this is just how I am!"

 God- this is going to be so much fun!  I love Little Women.  I need to re-read the book.  I'll do that this weekend, I think.

They're bringing in a guy to audition for Laurie on Saturday.  We may have another one show up as well.  I hope they're awesome.

And now I'm going to try to get some sleep.

Good night.

Life is good.

High School Musical is starting to come together for me.  We'll see how it goes for everyone else.

I love my job.

I have tomorrow night off starting around 5:30.  It's the first Friday that I've had off in seven weeks.  I'm going dancing, and it's going to rock.

Today, in the costume shop, I created this insanity for Hello, Dolly!



It's going to be part of some parade thing.  I think it's kinda cool.

< Marius and Enjorlas- Enjorlas' red vest. Fantine- Sleeves and (what you shouldn't be seeing) the red shift beneath (which comes in during "Lovely Ladies." You can see it on her right shoulder). Jean Valjean and Marius- "Bring Him Home." Valjean's pants and shirt. The Barricade- I have some stitching on almost every costume in the scene. Mainly pants as those were the things that we had the worst time with. Javert- Buttons on the coat. Valjean and Javert- Valjean's shirt and pants, Javert's vest and shirt. Enjorlas' death- Some work on the vest, and lots of work on the rest of the dead students. There you have it! I'm hoping someone will post a photo of Mme. Thernardier's hideous ball gown so you can see it too. Until then, these will have to do! Enjoy.

Oh my God.

I've been a serious theater-goer for over ten years.  We're talking real professional theater.  I imagine that the number of professional productions I've seen is startling.

Music Circus' Les Miserables is quite possibly The Best Show I've Ever Seen.

And I'm not exaggerating.

I'll be perfectly honest: I was nervous when I found out they were going to try to put that in the round.  I though it was going to suffer terribly.  I saw the show before when the National Tour came through Sacramento, and it was done on a traditional stage.  After loving that so dearly, I didn't think that seeing it in the round was going to be as good.

I was so wrong.  SO wrong.

First: AMAZING CAST.  Downright amazing.  Ivan Rutherford (Jean Valjean) is my hero.  So is Brad Little (Javert).  And Andrea Rivette (Fantine).

Second: AMAZING STAGING.  The direction was some of the best I have ever seen.  Period.  It was remarkable.  It all worked.  Nothing was awkward, nothing looked fake, nothing seemed like it had been specifically directed (I hate the over-directed look of so many shows I've seen).

Third: AMAZING SETS.  The Barricade worried me.  I had no idea how they were going to manage it.  I'm having a hard time describing it- but it was perfect.  Everything was clear, nothing was overdone, nothing was over-simplified.  It was just right.

Fourth: It was really cool to see my costumes up there.  I didn't realize how much stuff I'd worked on!  I think I did something to every outfit in "Lovely Ladies."  And my bigger projects turned out really well too!  Mme. Thernardier's ball gown was hideous (it's supposed to be).

I wish I didn't have such a busy schedule.  I would really like to see it again.

And tomorrow, I'm going to the Music Circus Opening Party.  It starts after the show and goes on til 2:00.  I can't wait to actually meet some of these people.

Anyway, it's late, I'm exhausted.  I'm going to bed.  Good night all.

I ROCK.

ok, sorry, I know I'm not that great yet, but I'm doing really well for myself right now!  I just got ANOTHER show.

Now Playing: Cinderella
Now Rehearsing: High School Musical
Rehearsing once HSM is Playing: The Broccoli Club

I just got notification of the Broccoli Club.  It's a world premier, and it looks like it's going to be hilarious.  I'm a Club singer, which should be a lot of fun.  I know that Jonathan (from Cinderella) got in as a supporting part, and I think Jeff (also from Cinderella) will be in it too considering how much they had him read for his part.  I'm really excited about this!  They've also asked me to do costumes for them (I'll be done working with Music Circus by then, so I'll have some more time to dedicate to that).  How cool to be in a world premier!  I will be the first person to ever play this part!  Weee!

ok- now I update my website and resume.  YAY!  My resume is getting more and more impressive!  The accompanist closed my binder of music after my audition and saw my resume (I have one slipped in the front cover) and inspected it.  He was really impressed (mainly by the five shows in 2007 and the leads/supporting roles that I've managed to get).

YAY!

Cinderella

Fair Oaks Theatre Festival & American River College

June 22 through July 29
Two Thursday Night Performances on July 19 & 26

All shows begin at 8:30

Veterans Memorial Amphiteatre in the Plaza Park in Old Fair Oaks Village at California Street and Fair Oaks Blvd.


I'm in the ensemble, and it's a fun little show.  The stepsisters and stepmother are played by men in drag, and... wow.  

As for things that I actually get to do: I'm in the opening number as a candy seller and my outfit is hilarious, I do a set change when the carriage comes on, I attend the Ball, I do another set change, I try on a shoe, I turn the page of the book (you'll see what I mean when you get there), and I attend the Wedding.  

Backstage, I am far more busy- I set props, help the stepsisters with costume changes, do my own costume changes (in record time and without revealing any skin- that's what four years of marching band will do to you), help with hair, and herd the little children into place.

Things you'll get to see if you come to this show: Costumes I worked on!  One of the few little children who I genuinely like, the AMAZING job I've done with some of the hair (Jonathan has long hair that he refuses to cut, so I've had to disguise it cleverly, and it looks really good), umm... me.  Me looking ridiculous.  Oh, wait, you see that all the time already...  Nevermind.

Tickets are $15 each.  (I know it's pricey for community theater, but I have no control over this.) The show is about an hour and a half, but I'm not sure what the full run-time with intermission(s) is...

If you're going to come, let me know.  If you don't let me know, then you are not allowed to hold me accountable for leaving the theater without saying hello and thank you.  (I've had this happen before- a guy from one of my classes went to a performance of HMS Pinafore and was very pissed off when I didn't stop to say hello to him.)

Seating is first come first serve.  I'm all over the stage- far left for the opening, far right for the Ball, far left for the waltz, far right again, center, left, right, center, and just right of center for the end.  (I get to be dead center for the curtain call!!!  I lead the bow and get to be the awesome one in the middle!!!!  *snerk* sorry- I'm kind of excited about that.  Of course, after we bow, I have to go way the hell down right, but it's all good.)  Basically, anywhere you sit will be good for seeing me.  I would avoid sitting in the first few rows at the extreme left and right of the house.  We have towers that I'm sure will obscure the view.

Hope I'll see some of you there!

All right- here I have some incredibly low low low quality screen shots of "Capital Eyes."  They were taken with a cell phone camera off of a computer screen.  I would've edited out reflections, but I'm too impatient to do that- so deal with it.



We start in the "real world" with me as Annie, wife to a not-so-successful novelist.  He's just been enjoying a good mope when I waltz in and decide he needs some inspiration.



This is the "Come on, sweetie!" look.  Annie thinks this will be loads of fun.  Brett (Brian) is considering it.



Above, we have the great Sam Hart, Private Eye.



Roxie, taunting Sam.  She wants him to do a job for her, but he's cautious.  He's been hurt by her before...



This is the "Please, Sam.  For old time's sake?" look.



Back to the real world.  Brett doesn't like Annie's idea of using a necklace as the MacGuffin.  She tells him to "Work with me here."



This is Sam's "I don't want your pity and I don't want your money.  You left me standing with my pants down ten years ago, and I want to know why!"



Which is immediately followed by Annie busting up laughing.



Brett decides he'll change it.



Here we have a gigantic leap forward in the story (because the shots from the rest were not the best...) Sam has just told Roxie off- she used him (he shot her husband, and she got all the money)- and here, he finally tells her goodbye for the last time.



Of course, back in the real world (between the last photo and this one) Annie protests the sad ending- and Brett considers and rewrites it!  So here we have Sam and Roxie, deciding to leave New York together.



And they all lived happily ever after.


Sorry about the huge number of photos- I'm sure I'm slowing down everyone's pages...  But I'm just too excited not to share!

Once the movie is posted, I'll share it too!

I got a copy of Captial Eyes today!!!!  Unfortunately, I can't share it with you all just yet.  Harpo wants to do a little more editing.

But I've got a few (terrible quality) screen shots for you- but I've got to be going to rehearsal (NOW) so I can't post them just yet.  I'll get them up here as soon as I get home.

Well- my part of "Captial Eyes" is finished.  Yes- Captial Eyes.  It's our new title.  None of us thinks it's great, but it'll do in a pinch.  We'll probably change it if we ever get around to extending the film.  But it does follow the pattern of having titles have little to do with what's actually in the film.

I got to see more of what Harpo's put together- and once the sound work and music is all in, I think it'll be really cool.  Some of the shots are absolutely stunning!  There's one of Brian smoking- the camera follows his hand as he strikes a match and lights a cigarette then pans out to show him.  It's awesome.  Then, there's the insane dolley shot of Brian writing furiously which also turned out beautifully.

Harpo is very proud of a shot of me as I leave the office, but I'm not as thrilled with it as he is.  It's kind of funny- I look at Brian, then down, then turn away and walk out the door.  The turn away part is what makes me laugh.  I'm wearing all black (I'm in mourining, my husband has just been shot) and I've got dark hair, and I'm standing in front of a door of some sort of dark-ish wood.  The part where I'm looking at Brian looks great, but I turn away and pretty much disappear!  It's really funny.  Since it's in black and white, with all the dark colors in the shot- it all runs together and I vanish!  So- hopefully, Harpo will do something to make me not vanish like that.

Anyhow- voice overs!  It's really tough, especially when you have to match up with the film.  Harpo would play what I was supposed to say, then I'd have to match it as well as I could.  Then, Harpo would do a little editing to make sure that it was as close as we could make it.  The shots where we didn't have to match exactly (if my face wasn't shown) were a lot easier (of course).

I hope that everything comes together just so- it'll be really cool if it does.

And it's going to be finished today- I think by noon.  I'll post it somewhere when I can.  I'm excited!
